Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evaluating the Roles of Factors Critical to MJO Simulations Using the NCAR CAM3 with Deterministic and Stochastic Convection Parameterization Closures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is a large-scale pattern of precipitation and atmospheric circulation anomalies which forms over the Indian Ocean and propagates slowly eastward towards the central equatorial Pacific Ocean. Impacts of the MJO are felt over much of the earth, and the presence of the MJO in the central equatorial Pacific Ocean exerts a strong modulation of hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico. Work conducted under this grant is intended to improve the representation of the MJO in global climate models (GCMs), particularly the National Center for Atmospheric Research Community Atmosphere Model (CAM). The questions addressed in the research focus on specific factors believed to be essential to a successful MJO simulation: 1) How important is convective momentum transport [CMT, occurring in cumulus clouds] in the MJO simulation? The objective of addressing this question is to understand what role convective momentum transport plays in westerly wind bursts accompanying MJOs. 2) What are the roles of convective versus stratiform heating, shallow versus deep convection, and stochastic versus deterministic convection closure in the MJO simulation? The objective is to determine how each of the processes affects the MJO simulation [here stratiform refers to the flat, upper-level "anvils" associated with deep cumulus clouds]. 3) How do these roles depend on the MJO phases in the MJO development process? The objective of answering this question is to understand what role each process plays during different stages of the MJO evolution. Motivation for the work comes from the difficulty in simulating and predicting the MJO using weather and climate models.

The work has broader impacts due to the many worldwide impacts of the MJO on weather and climate, as better representation of the MJO in models is a first step in generating useful MJO forecasts. In addition, the MJO is an important test case for the parameterization of convection and cloud processes in climate models, which would increase our confidence in predictions and projections of climate change. Beyond these broader impacts, the project also promotes science education through undergraduate teaching and outreach activities to high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of our project includes (A) significant contributions to climate research through modeling studies using the NCAR global climate model; (B) development of new research tools and datasets for understanding the intraseasonal variability; (C) production of new scientific results on roles of different factors in the evolution of the intraseasonal Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) and its physical mechanisms; and (D) training five graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers. Our key scientific products are (i) 14 referred journal publications; (ii) a critical parameterization scheme for convective microphysical processes in global climate models; and (iii) daily Tibetan Plateau snow cover data. Our research outcome has made significant advancement in the following six aspects of MJO research:

(1)  A better understanding of what affects MJO: Through numerical experiments by including and excluding shallow convection in the NCAR global climate model, it was found that the global simulation including shallow convection shows a clear lower tropospheric moistening at the beginning and developing stages of the MJO lifetime. This is interpreted as preconditioning by a combined effect of vertical advection and convection. This is confirmed by the simulation excluding shallow convection, which does not show positive moisture anomaly in the lower troposphere before systematic deep convection starts.

(2)   A diagnostics method for identifying fields important to MJO simulations: We developed a diagnostics method to relate model simulation biases to model physics deficiencies. By nudging the model-simulated fields to reanalysis or observational data, we showed that nudging tendencies are a good measure of model physics parameterization errors. Our nudging experiments indicate that the moisture field is an important factor to MJO simulation, followed by wind fields, while the temperature field appears to be the least important. The diagnosis of such nudging tendencies provides an efficient and objective way to identify model biases from physical parameterizations.

(3)  A convective microphysics parameterization scheme for global climate models: In order to investigate how condensational heating from microphysical processes in convection affects MJO simulation, we developed a convective microphysics parameterization scheme and implemented it into the NCAR global climate model CAM5. Our parameterization scheme accounts for many microphysical processes and their interaction. NCAR is making further evaluation on our scheme to consider the scheme’s inclusion in its code repository.

(4)  Identification of best convective trigger functions: Using observational data, we evaluated convective trigger functions used in global climate models in the world’s major modeling centers. The key variables used to define these trigger functions were examined in detail. Generation of convective instability incorporating entrainment dilution by large-scale flow forms the best indicator for convection onset in both tropical and midlatitude convective environments. The low-level vertical motion below the lifting condensation level in the convective parameterization of the ECMWF global model is another indicator. These provide a useful guide for parameterization developers

(5)  A dataset for assessing MJO’s effect: We produced a dataset of daily snow cover for the Tibetan Plateau (TP) region (25°-45°N, 65°-105°E) from February 4, 1997, in order to quantitatively assess the MJO’s influence on the TP snow cover, which influences the eastern China’s monsoon-driven convective precipitation.
